Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Situation2: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Story: I glanced at the clock above the register—ten minutes until the team meeting started. As a colleague, I was expected to join, to listen and contribute, especially since today’s agenda included project updates that wouldn’t be shared later. But as a cashier, I was the only one on shift, and even though the store was quiet, a few customers had just walked in. I smiled and greeted them, scanning their items and making small talk, trying to keep the line moving smoothly. My phone buzzed in my pocket: a reminder for the meeting. I felt the pressure mounting. If I left the register to join the meeting, I’d be letting down the customers and my manager, who counted on me for friendly, reliable service. But if I stayed, I’d miss out on crucial information and risk falling behind at work. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—my team needed me, but so did the people right in front of me. I looked from the register to the door, torn between two worlds, unsure which one I could afford to disappoint.
